<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Three 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymers and one metallomacrocycle bridged by 2,2′:5′,4″-terpyridine were prepared under the direction of anions and solvents and they have been characterized structurally.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Three 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymers and one metallomacrocycle bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpyridine were prepared under the direction of anions and solvents and they have been characterized structurally.

In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the tetrahedral Cu(I) atoms are bridged by 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in the head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there are two independent infinite 1-D zigzag chain structures along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axises in the unit cell. The weak intermolecular π⋯π stacking interactions exist between opposite 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy ligands. The PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> anions are surrounded by four opposite MeCN molecules in two crossed zigzag chains. In contrast, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO/MeCN under Ar/C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> afforded Cu(I) metallomacrocycle [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Four Cu(I) atoms are bridged by the four 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in a head-to-tail fashion to afford a rhombic Cu(I) metallomacrocycle. One distorted Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO molecule is encapsulated in the central vacant space of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> core and two PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> anions are sandwiched between the rhombic Cu(I) metallomacrocyclic layers. The reactions of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Cu turnings with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymer {[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). It has been proved that complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> could be induced by the autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Constructions of Cu(I) metallomacrocycles bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpyridine.

Constructions of Cu(I) coordination polymers bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpyridine.

Self-assemblies of Cu(I) metallomacrocycles and coordination polymers directed by anions and solvents.

Abstract

The reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]X (X=BF4, PF6) with 2,2':5',4"-terpyridine (2,2':5',4"-terpy) in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymers {[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]BF4}n (1) and {{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2). In complex 1, the tetrahedral Cu(I) atoms are bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure. In complex 2, there are two independent infinite 1-D zigzag chain structures along the b- and c-axises in the unit cell. The weak intermolecular π⋯π stacking interactions exist between opposite 2,2':5',4"-terpy ligands. The PF6 - anions are surrounded by four opposite MeCN molecules in two crossed zigzag chains. In contrast, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in Me2CO/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded Cu(I) metallomacrocycle [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3). Four Cu(I) atoms are bridged by the four 2,2':5',4"-terpy in a head-to-tail fashion to afford a rhombic Cu(I) metallomacrocycle. One distorted Me2CO molecule is encapsulated in the central vacant space of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core and two PF6 - anions are sandwiched between the rhombic Cu(I) metallomacrocyclic layers. The reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and Cu turnings with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymer {[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]NO3}n (4). It has been proved that complex 4 could be induced by the autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">For the past few decade, supramolecular chemistry has provided important advances in developing strategies for the synthesis of complex molecular architectures . One of the approaches used to prepare such inorganic and organic molecular assemblies involves chemical templates . This strategy not only enables the synthesis of molecules in a more efficient manner but also aids in the preparation of assemblies that have unusual topologies such as macrocycles , cages , helicates , rotaxanes  and catenanes . A template can be considered as an entity that contains the required information to help organize a collection of building blocks in a specific manner. The templation process can be thermodynamically or kinetically driven. A thermodynamic template binds to one of the products by shifting the equilibrium so that this specific product is obtained in high yields and selectively formed over other potential products. On the other hand, a kinetic template operates under irreversible conditions by stabilizing the transition states that lead to the formation of the desired product. In order for a template process to successfully yield the targeted product, the structural and electrostatic properties of the template need to be selected carefully. From a structural point of view, both the size and geometry of the template have to be considered, while the choice is electrostatically restricted to neutral, positively charged or negatively charged species. Although cationic and neutral species have been widely used as templates in synthetic chemistry, the role of anion templates was scarcely exploited until the second half of the 1990s. The slower development of an anion-templated process is partially attributable to the complicated physicochemical nature of the anions such as their diffuse nature, variety of geometries, pH sensitivity and relatively high solvation-free energies. Subsequently, the potential use of anion species as templates has been demonstrated by the increasing number of anion-directed assemblies in a wide range of novel inorganic and organic assemblies .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

For the past few decade, supramolecular chemistry has provided important advances in developing strategies for the synthesis of complex molecular architectures . One of the approaches used to prepare such inorganic and organic molecular assemblies involves chemical templates . This strategy not only enables the synthesis of molecules in a more efficient manner but also aids in the preparation of assemblies that have unusual topologies such as macrocycles , cages , helicates , rotaxanes  and catenanes . A template can be considered as an entity that contains the required information to help organize a collection of building blocks in a specific manner. The templation process can be thermodynamically or kinetically driven. A thermodynamic template binds to one of the products by shifting the equilibrium so that this specific product is obtained in high yields and selectively formed over other potential products. On the other hand, a kinetic template operates under irreversible conditions by stabilizing the transition states that lead to the formation of the desired product. In order for a template process to successfully yield the targeted product, the structural and electrostatic properties of the template need to be selected carefully. From a structural point of view, both the size and geometry of the template have to be considered, while the choice is electrostatically restricted to neutral, positively charged or negatively charged species. Although cationic and neutral species have been widely used as templates in synthetic chemistry, the role of anion templates was scarcely exploited until the second half of the 1990s. The slower development of an anion-templated process is partially attributable to the complicated physicochemical nature of the anions such as their diffuse nature, variety of geometries, pH sensitivity and relatively high solvation-free energies. Subsequently, the potential use of anion species as templates has been demonstrated by the increasing number of anion-directed assemblies in a wide range of novel inorganic and organic assemblies .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">4-(2-pyridyl)pyrimidine (pprd) is an attractive <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donor ligand with a bidentate site for chelating and an exo <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donor site for bridging . It is expected to produce both finite metallomacrocyclic and infinite polymeric compounds with square/rectangle motifs. So far, we have proved that Cu(I)-pprd/{C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, CO} metallomacrocycles encapsulating ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> and BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> anions  and Cu(I)-pprd/X coordination polymers bridged by halogen ions (X = Cl, Br, I)  could be preferentially self-assembled by the controls of anions and solvents, together with sandwich-shaped Ag(I)-pprd metallomacrocycles encapsulating XF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2–</ce:sup> anions (X = Si, Ge and Sn) . Furthermore, Cu(I)-{bpm, Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpm}/C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> coordination polymers could be also constructed by the use of 4,4′-bipyrimidine (bpm) and 6,6′-dimethyl-4,4′-bipyrimidine (Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpm) with a bidentate site for chelating and two exo <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-donor site for bridging . As a further investigation, we prepared 2,2′:5′,4″-terpyridine (2,2′:5′,4″-terpy) with a longer arm of 4-pyridyl group as the related pprd ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). We attempted to synthesize novel metallomacrocyclic and coordination polymers bridged by 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy under the direction of anions and solvents. One Cu(I) metallomacrocycle and three coordination polymers with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy were isolated and they have been structurally characterized by IR, UV–VIS and X-ray analysis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 4-(2-pyridyl)pyrimidine (pprd) is an attractive N-donor ligand with a bidentate site for chelating and an exo N-donor site for bridging . It is expected to produce both finite metallomacrocyclic and infinite polymeric compounds with square/rectangle motifs. So far, we have proved that Cu(I)-pprd/{C2H4, CO} metallomacrocycles encapsulating ClO4 -, PF6 - and BF4 - anions  and Cu(I)-pprd/X coordination polymers bridged by halogen ions (X=Cl, Br, I)  could be preferentially self-assembled by the controls of anions and solvents, together with sandwich-shaped Ag(I)-pprd metallomacrocycles encapsulating XF6 2- anions (X=Si, Ge and Sn) . Furthermore, Cu(I)-{bpm, Me2bpm}/C2H4 coordination polymers could be also constructed by the use of 4,4'-bipyrimidine (bpm) and 6,6'-dimethyl-4,4'-bipyrimidine (Me2bpm) with a bidentate site for chelating and two exo N-donor site for bridging . As a further investigation, we prepared 2,2':5',4"-terpyridine (2,2':5',4"-terpy) with a longer arm of 4-pyridyl group as the related pprd ligand ( ). We attempted to synthesize novel metallomacrocyclic and coordination polymers bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpy under the direction of anions and solvents. One Cu(I) metallomacrocycle and three coordination polymers with 2,2':5',4"-terpy were isolated and they have been structurally characterized by IR, UV-VIS and X-ray analysis.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">General procedures and reagents</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The precursor Cu(I) complexes, [Cu(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]X (X = BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>) were prepared according to the literatures . The C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (>99.9%) and Ar (>99.999%) gases were purchased from Sumitomo Seika Chemicals and Taiyo Nippon Sanso, respectively. All organic solvents were dried and distilled by usual methods before use. All procedures were carried out using standard Schlenk techniques. <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra were measured on a JEOL GSX-400 at room temperature. IR spectra were recorded with a JASCO FT-IR 4600 spectrometer as KBr pellets. The diffuse-reflectance UV–VIS spectra were recorded with a HITACHI U-4100 spectrophotometer as the sample (0.01 mmol) doped in MgO powder (80 mg) and then the spectra converted using the Kubelka-Munk function .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures and reagents

The precursor Cu(I) complexes, [Cu(MeCN)4]X (X=BF4 and PF6) were prepared according to the literatures . The C2H4 (>99.9%) and Ar (>99.999%) gases were purchased from Sumitomo Seika Chemicals and Taiyo Nippon Sanso, respectively. All organic solvents were dried and distilled by usual methods before use. All procedures were carried out using standard Schlenk techniques. 1H NMR spectra were measured on a JEOL GSX-400 at room temperature. IR spectra were recorded with a JASCO FT-IR 4600 spectrometer as KBr pellets. The diffuse-reflectance UV-VIS spectra were recorded with a HITACHI U-4100 spectrophotometer as the sample (0.01mmol) doped in MgO powder (80mg) and then the spectra converted using the Kubelka-Munk function .

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 2,2':5',4"-terpy

The 2,2':5',4"-terpy ligand was prepared by the reactions of 5-bromo-2,2'-bipyridine (1.1g, 4.68mmol) with [Pd(PPh3)2Cl2] (0.298g, 0.426mmol) and 4-(trimethylstannyl)pyridine (2.04g, 8.50mmol) in toluene at 125°C for 4days by reference to the literature method . The reaction products were recrystallized from MeOH. Yields. 0.81g (73.6%). 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3, 23°C): 8.97 (H6', dd, 4 J=2.4Hz, 1H), 8.75 (H2'',6'', dd, 3 J=4.9Hz, 2H), 8.73 (H6, dt, 3 J=4.9Hz, 1H), 8.54 (H3, d, 3 J=8.3Hz, 1H), 8.45 (H3', dt, 3 J=7.8Hz, 1H), 8.10 (H4', dd, 3 J=8.3Hz, 1H), 7.86 (H4, td, 3 J=7.8Hz, 1H), 7.58 (H3'',5'', dd, 3 J=4.9Hz, 2H) and 7.36 (H5, td, 3 J=4.9Hz, 1H). The 1H NMR spectrum of 2,2':5',4"-terpy was shown in .

After the red reaction solution was bubbled by C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, a yellowish-brown solution was filtered. elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy complexes

{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]BF4}n (1)

[Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 (62.9mg, 0.20mmol) and 2,2':5',4"-terpy (23.3mg, 0.10mmol) were reacted in MeOH/MeCN (10.0mL, v/v=9:1) under Ar. After the red reaction solution was bubbled by C2H4, a yellowish-brown solution was filtered. The filtrates were sealed in 7 mmϕ glass tubes together with pentane (v/v=1/1) under C2H4. The reaction solution was allowed to stand for 4weeks at room temperature and prism red crystals of complex 1 were obtained. Yields. 22.8mg (53.7%). Anal. Calcd. for CuC17H14BF4N4: C, 48.08; H, 3.32; N, 13.19. Found: C,48.36; H, 3.48; N, 13.48. IR (cm-1, Solid, KBr): 1602(s), 1470(s), 1440(s), 1387(m), 1237(m), 1060(s, BF4), 830(s), 792(s), 752(m), 723(m) and 521(m). UV-VIS (nm, Solid, MgO): λmax=400.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st070">X-ray crystal structure determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The measurements of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were made on a Rigaku XtaLAB-PRO MM007-PILATUS-200 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The diffraction data were collected at 100(2) K for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> by the ω scan mode. Data were collected and processed using the CrysAlisPro (Rigaku Oxford Diffraction). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure determinations

The measurements of complexes 1-4 were made on a Rigaku XtaLAB-PRO MM007-PILATUS-200 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71075Å). The diffraction data were collected at 100(2) K for complexes 1-4 by the ω scan mode. Data were collected and processed using the CrysAlisPro (Rigaku Oxford Diffraction). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXTL) and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically (SHELXL2017/1). All hydrogen atoms were refined using the AFIX command. In complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the disordered PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup>, Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules were restrained to the same thermal displacement parameter and bond lengths and angles using the EADP, DFIX, and DANG commands, respectively. All calculations were performed using Olex2 (ver. 1.2). Crystal data and detailed structure determinations are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXTL) and expanded using Fourier techniques. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically (SHELXL2017/1). All hydrogen atoms were refined using the AFIX command. In complexes 1-4, the disordered PF6 -, Me2CO and H2O molecules were restrained to the same thermal displacement parameter and bond lengths and angles using the EADP, DFIX, and DANG commands, respectively. All calculations were performed using Olex2 (ver. 1.2). Crystal data and detailed structure determinations are summarized in  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st080">Crystal structures of Cu(I)-2,2′:5′,4″-terpy complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st085">{[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The reaction of [Cu(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> afforded prism red crystals of {[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The X-ray crystal analysis showed that the Cu(1) atom is coordinated by one N atom in the terminal site of 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy, one N atom of MeCN and two N atoms in the chelate site of another 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in the tetrahedral geometry. Furthermore, these Cu(I) atoms are bridged by 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in the head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). Although only two examples of mononuclear Ru(II)  and dinuclear Ir(III)/Co(III) complexes  containing 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy could be found in the literatures, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be considered as the first Cu(I) coordination polymer bridged by 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy. As described in introduction, we have reported that the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> with pprd under C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> preferentially afforded trinuclrar Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(pprd)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and chair-like hexanuclear Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(pprd)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> in our previous works . Therefore, this result shows that the infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure is different from structures of previous Cu(I)-pprd-C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> complexes . The C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> could not serve here as an ancillary ligand due to the stronger coordination ability of MeCN.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structures of Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy complexes

{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]BF4}n (1)

The reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded prism red crystals of {[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]BF4}n (1). The X-ray crystal analysis showed that the Cu(1) atom is coordinated by one N atom in the terminal site of 2,2':5',4"-terpy, one N atom of MeCN and two N atoms in the chelate site of another 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the tetrahedral geometry. Furthermore, these Cu(I) atoms are bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure ( ). Although only two examples of mononuclear Ru(II)  and dinuclear Ir(III)/Co(III) complexes  containing 2,2':5',4"-terpy could be found in the literatures, complex 1 can be considered as the first Cu(I) coordination polymer bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpy. As described in introduction, we have reported that the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 with pprd under C2H4 preferentially afforded trinuclrar Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu3(pprd)2(MeCN)2(C2H4)2](BF4)3 and chair-like hexanuclear Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu6(pprd)6(C2H4)6](BF4)6 in our previous works . Therefore, this result shows that the infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure is different from structures of previous Cu(I)-pprd-C2H4 complexes . The C2H4 could not serve here as an ancillary ligand due to the stronger coordination ability of MeCN.

{{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2)

To investigate the role of an anion in the formation process relative to complex 1, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 (in place of a BF4 - anion) with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded brick reddish brown crystals of {{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2). Unlike complex 1, there are two independent infinite 1-D zigzag chain structures containing Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms in the unit cell ( ). Both Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms are coordinated by one N atom in the terminal site of 2,2':5',4"-terpy, one N atom of MeCN and two N atoms in the chelate site of another 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the tetrahedral geometry. Although two independent 1-D zigzag chain structures apparently have a similar structure, it should be noted that one infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure (chains (a): blue) containing the Cu(1) atom are extended along the c-axis and the other infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure (chains (b): green) containing the Cu(2) atom are extended along the b-axis. The crossed zigzag chains are stacking parallel to each other against the ac plane ( ). In both of the chains (a) and (b), the weak intermolecular π⋯π stacking interactions meaningfully exist between opposite 2,2':5',4"-terpy ligands in the adjacent zigzag chains [the chain (a): centroid⋯centroid distance between central pyridyl rings=3.623Å, internal angle between central pyridyl rings=0°, centroid⋯centroid distance between terminal 2-pyridyl ring and terminal 4-pyridyl ring=3.653Å, internal angle between terminal 2-pyridyl ring and terminal 4-pyridyl ring=5.58°; the chain (b): centroid⋯centroid distance between central pyridyl ring and terminal 2-pyridyl ring=3.567Å, internal angle between central pyridyl ring and terminal 2-pyridyl ring=4.34°]. Another remarkably structural feature is that the PF6 - anions are surrounded by four opposite MeCN molecules in two crossed zigzag chains (a) and (b). In our previous works, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 with pprd under C2H4 afforded polymeric Cu(I)-pprd complex {[Cu(pprd)(C2H4)]PF6}n and tetranuclear Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu4(pprd)4(C2H4)4](PF6)4 . Therefore, the infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure is different from structures of complex 1 and the previous Cu(I)-pprd-C2H4 complexes . This result indicates that the PF6 - anions can play here a significant role as an anion template to form the crossed zigzag chain structure.

[Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3)

To investigate the role of a solvent in the formation process relative to complex 2, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in Me2CO/MeCN (in place of MeOH/MeCN) under Ar/C2H4 afforded plate orange crystals of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3). Unlike complexes 1 and 2, the X-ray crystal analysis showed that there are one [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ cation moiety, four PF6 - anions and five solvated Me2CO molecules in a unit cell. Four Cu(I) atoms are bridged by the four 2,2':5',4"-terpy in a head-to-tail fashion to afford a rhombic Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy metallomacrocycle ( (a)). The Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) and Cu(1)⋯Cu(2') distances are 9.742 and 10.077Å, and the internal Cu(1)⋯Cu(2)⋯Cu(1') and Cu(2)⋯Cu(1)⋯Cu(2') angles are 103.80 and 76.20°. It should be noted that these rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ cores are stacking parallel to each other against the bc plane (along the a-axis). The one side of four sides in the rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core is alternately overlapping at intervals of the Cu(I)⋯Cu(I) contact of 3.402Å. Furthermore, one distorted Me2CO molecule is encapsulated in the central vacant space of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core and two PF6 - anions are sandwiched between the rhombic Cu(I) metallomacrocyclic layers ((b)). Therefore, this result shows that the PF6 - anions and the Me2CO molecules can serve here as a template to form a rhombic tetranuclear Cu(I) metallomacrocycle. The planar structure of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core is different from the matallocalix[4]-shaped structure of Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu4(pprd)4(C2H4)4](PF6)4 encapsulating PF6 - anion in our previous works .

The N(6′)-Cu(1)-N(5′) angle of 80.76° is larger than two other <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-Cu(1)-N angles (N(6′)-Cu(1)-N(1) = 151.38, N(5′)-Cu(1)-N(1) = 127.84°). In similarly, the Cu(2)-N(3) distance of 2.092 Å is slightly longer than two other Cu(2)-N distances (Cu(2)-N(2) = 1.960 Å, Cu(2)-N(4) = 1.905 Å) around the Cu(2) atom. The N(2)-Cu(2)-N(3) angle of 81.62° is larger than two other <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-Cu(2)-N angles (N(2)-Cu(2)-N(4) = 157.31°, N(3)-Cu(2)-N(4) = 121.07°). In addition, the sum of the three internal angles around the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atom are 359.98° and 360.00°, respectively. Therefore, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms have a unique Y-shape triangular planar structure . In the short side of rhombic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> core, the dihedral angle of 25.95° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (C) is larger than that (6.32°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (A). The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(2), N(4), C(16) and C(20)} and {Cu(2), N(2) and N(3)} atoms is 26.01° around the Cu(2) atom. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in (c).</ce:para>

Therefore, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms have a unique Y-shape triangular planar structure . Unlike complexes 1 and 2, MeCN is not coordinate to the Cu(I) atom as an ancillary ligand. In the short side of rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core, the dihedral angle of 25.95° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (C) is larger than that (6.32°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (A). Similarly, in the long side, the dihedral angle of 19.97° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (E) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (F) is larger than that (4.83°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (E) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (D). The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(1), N(1), C(1) and C(5)} and {Cu(1), N(5') and N(6')} atoms is 21.24° around the Cu(1) atom. The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(2), N(4), C(16) and C(20)} and {Cu(2), N(2) and N(3)} atoms is 26.01° around the Cu(2) atom. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in (c).

<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> and PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> anions in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the reactions of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Cu turnings with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar afforded prism red crystals of {[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). The X-ray crystal analysis showed that the Cu(1) atom is coordinated by one N atom in the terminal site of 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy, one N atom of MeCN and two N atoms in the chelate site of another 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in the tetrahedral geometry. The Cu(I) atoms are bridged by 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in the head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). Although the structural appearance and crystal packing structure of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> basically resemble to those of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> anion is not coordinate to the Cu(I) atom as an ancillary ligand. Therefore, this result is different from the formation of the related dinuclear Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pprd)(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in our previous works . It is most noteworthy that complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> could be induced by the autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species under Ar. To our knowledge, although only few Cu(I) complexes have been produced by the autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species , complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> can be described as one of very rare examples.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]NO3}n (4)

As an alternative to BF4 - and PF6 - anions in complexes 1-3, the reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and Cu turnings with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar afforded prism red crystals of {[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]NO3}n (4). The X-ray crystal analysis showed that the Cu(1) atom is coordinated by one N atom in the terminal site of 2,2':5',4"-terpy, one N atom of MeCN and two N atoms in the chelate site of another 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the tetrahedral geometry. The Cu(I) atoms are bridged by 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure along the b-axis ( ). Although the structural appearance and crystal packing structure of complex 4 basically resemble to those of complex 1, the NO3 - anion is not coordinate to the Cu(I) atom as an ancillary ligand. Therefore, this result is different from the formation of the related dinuclear Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu2(pprd)(C2H4)(NO3)]NO3 in our previous works . It is most noteworthy that complex 4 could be induced by the autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species under Ar. To our knowledge, although only few Cu(I) complexes have been produced by the autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species , complex 4 can be described as one of very rare examples.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0105" view="all">The Cu–N distance and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-Cu(1)-N angles are similar to those of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In contrast, the dihedral angle of 7.50° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (A) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (C) is slightly smaller than that (10.94°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (A). Therefore, the coordinated 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy plane has a more planar structure relative to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The dihedral angle of 69.51° between two planes defined by {Cu(1), N(1), C(1) and C(5)} and {Cu(1), N(2′) and N(3′)} atoms around the Cu(1) atom is slightly smaller than the corresponding angle (67.98°) in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In a similar manner to complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the infinite 1-D zigzag-chains are apparently stacking parallel to each other against the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane, along with the centroid⋯centroid distance (3.749 Å) and the inter-planar angle (7.50°) between the opposite central 2-pyridyl ring and terminal 4-pyridyl ring. However, the Cu(I)⋯Cu(I) distance of 6.468 Å is located far away from that (6.364 Å) in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. It is considered that there is no specific intermolecular interaction such as π⋯π stacking, C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯π and Cu(I)⋯Cu(I) interactions judging from the distances and the angles. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in (d).</ce:para>

Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> showed the IR absorption bands for ν<ce:inf loc="post">C=C,</ce:inf> ν<ce:inf loc="post">C=N,</ce:inf> ν<ce:inf loc="post">C-C,</ce:inf> ν<ce:inf loc="post">C-N</ce:inf> stretching vibrations in the ranges of <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 1600–1300 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in  and . elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic characterizations of Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy complexes

Complexes 1-4 are insoluble in normal organic solvents. We are currently unable to obtain appropriate UV-VIS and 1H NMR spectra in solution. Alternatively, we have characterized spectroscopically complexes 1-4 by IR and UV-VIS measurements in the solid state. Complexes 1-4 showed the IR absorption bands for νC=C, νC=N, νC-C, νC-N stretching vibrations in the ranges of ca. 1600-1300cm-1 in  and . These IR absorption patterns were changed relative to those of metal-free 2,2':5',4"-terpy in  and , along with the strong absorption bands of 1060 (BF4), 840 (PF6), 844 (PF6) and 1363 (NO3) cm-1 for complexes 1-4, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The UV−VIS spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in the solid state are shown in . Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> gave the relatively distinct absorption at λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> = 400, 400 and 425 nm, respectively, whereas complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibited the gentle absorption at λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> = 410 nm as a shoulder. These absorptions were assigned as the charge-transfer transition (MLCT) band from the dπ(Cu) orbital to the π*(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy) orbital.</ce:para>

Complex 1, 2 and 4 gave the relatively distinct absorption at λmax=400, 400 and 425nm, respectively, whereas complex 3 exhibited the gentle absorption at λmax=410nm as a shoulder. These absorptions were assigned as the charge-transfer transition (MLCT) band from the dπ(Cu) orbital to the π*(2,2':5',4"-terpy) orbital.

<ce:section-title id="st110">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In place of the pprd ligand , the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]X (X = BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>) with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymers {[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {{[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) depending on anions and solvents. On the other hand, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO/MeCN under Ar/C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> afforded Cu(I) metallomacrocycle [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·5Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Furthermore, the reactions of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Cu turnings with 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymer {[Cu(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)(MeCN)]NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), along with the unique autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species. We demonstrated the self-assembles of Cu(I) metallomacrocycle and coordination polymers under the direction of anions and solvents, in combination with previous results regarding the related Cu(I)-pprd/{C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, CO} metallomacrocycles encapsulating ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> and BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">–</ce:sup> anions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In place of the pprd ligand , the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]X (X=BF4, PF6) with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymers {[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]BF4}n (1) and {{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2) depending on anions and solvents. On the other hand, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in Me2CO/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded Cu(I) metallomacrocycle [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3). Furthermore, the reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and Cu turnings with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar afforded 1-D Cu(I) coordination polymer {[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]NO3}n (4), along with the unique autoreduction of Cu(II) species to Cu(I) species. We demonstrated the self-assembles of Cu(I) metallomacrocycle and coordination polymers under the direction of anions and solvents, in combination with previous results regarding the related Cu(I)-pprd/{C2H4, CO} metallomacrocycles encapsulating ClO4 -, PF6 - and BF4 - anions .

Synthesis of 2,2':5',4"-terpy

The 2,2':5',4"-terpy ligand was prepared by the reactions of 5-bromo-2,2'-bipyridine (1.1g, 4.68mmol) with [Pd(PPh3)2Cl2] (0.298g, 0.426mmol) and 4-(trimethylstannyl)pyridine (2.04g, 8.50mmol) in toluene at 125°C for 4days by reference to the literature method . The reaction products were recrystallized from MeOH. Yields. 0.81g (73.6%). 1H NMR (δ, CDCl3, 23°C): 8.97 (H6', dd, 4 J=2.4Hz, 1H), 8.75 (H2'',6'', dd, 3 J=4.9Hz, 2H), 8.73 (H6, dt, 3 J=4.9Hz, 1H), 8.54 (H3, d, 3 J=8.3Hz, 1H), 8.45 (H3', dt, 3 J=7.8Hz, 1H), 8.10 (H4', dd, 3 J=8.3Hz, 1H), 7.86 (H4, td, 3 J=7.8Hz, 1H), 7.58 (H3'',5'', dd, 3 J=4.9Hz, 2H) and 7.36 (H5, td, 3 J=4.9Hz, 1H). The 1H NMR spectrum of 2,2':5',4"-terpy was shown in .

Syntheses of Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy complexes

{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]BF4}n (1)

[Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 (62.9mg, 0.20mmol) and 2,2':5',4"-terpy (23.3mg, 0.10mmol) were reacted in MeOH/MeCN (10.0mL, v/v=9:1) under Ar. After the red reaction solution was bubbled by C2H4, a yellowish-brown solution was filtered. The filtrates were sealed in 7 mmϕ glass tubes together with pentane (v/v=1/1) under C2H4. The reaction solution was allowed to stand for 4weeks at room temperature and prism red crystals of complex 1 were obtained. Yields. 22.8mg (53.7%). Anal. Calcd. for CuC17H14BF4N4: C, 48.08; H, 3.32; N, 13.19. Found: C,48.36; H, 3.48; N, 13.48. IR (cm-1, Solid, KBr): 1602(s), 1470(s), 1440(s), 1387(m), 1237(m), 1060(s, BF4), 830(s), 792(s), 752(m), 723(m) and 521(m). UV-VIS (nm, Solid, MgO): λmax=400.

{{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2)

[Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 (74.5mg, 0.20mmol) and 2,2':5',4"-terpy (23.3mg, 0.10mmol) were reacted in MeOH/MeCN (10.0mL, v/v=9:1) under Ar. After the red reaction solution was bubbled by C2H4, a yellowish-brown solution was filtered. The filtrates were sealed in 7 mmϕ glass tubes together with pentane (v/v=1/1) under C2H4. The reaction solution was allowed to stand for 4weeks at room temperature and brick reddish brown crystals of complex 2 were obtained. Yields. 18.0mg (36.6%). Anal. Calcd. for Cu2C34H30F12N8OP2: C, 41.51; H, 3.07; N, 11.39. Found: C, 41.21; H, 3.63; N, 11.67. IR (cm-1, Solid, KBr): 1605(m), 1470(m), 1439(m), 840(s, PF6), 793(m) and 558(m). UV-VIS (nm, Solid, MgO): λmax=400.

[Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3)

[Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 (74.5mg, 0.20mmol) and 2,2':5',4"-terpy (23.3mg, 0.10mmol) were reacted in Me2CO/MeCN (10.0mL, v/v=9:1) under Ar. After the brown reaction solution was bubbled by C2H4, a yellowish-brown solution was filtered. The filtrates were sealed in 7 mmϕ glass tubes together with pentane (v/v=1/1) under C2H4. The reaction solution was allowed to stand for 1week at room temperature and plate orange crystals of complex 3 were obtained. Yields. 27.0mg (52.4%). Anal. Calcd. for Cu4C75H74F24N12O5P4: C, 43.78; H, 3.63; N, 8.17. Found: C, 43.60; H, 3.50; N, 8.49. IR (cm-1, Solid, KBr): 1715(m), 1614(s), 1471(s), 1440(s), 1380(s), 1320(m), 1237(m), 844(s, PF6), 795(s), 730(s) and 558(s). UV-VIS (nm, Solid, MgO): λmax=410 (shoulder).

{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]NO3}n (4)

Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (24.2mg, 0.10mmol), Cu turnings and 2,2':5',4"-terpy (23.3mg, 0.10mmol) were reacted in MeOH/MeCN (10.0mL, v/v=9:1) under Ar. After a red solution was filtered, the filtrate was sealed in 7 mmϕ glass tubes together with pentane (v/v=1/1) under Ar. The reaction solution was allowed to stand for 4weeks at room temperature. Prism red crystals of complex 4 were collected. Yields. 9.6mg (24%). Anal. Calcd. for CuC17H14N5O3: C, 51.06; H, 3.53; N, 17.51. Found: C, 51.35; H, 3.76; N, 17.88. IR (cm-1, Solid, KBr): 1603(m), 1469m), 1437(m), 1363(s, NO3), 827(m), 793(m), 751(m) and 724(m). UV-VIS (nm, Solid, MgO): λmax=425.

For this reason, two neighboring 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy are largely bent each other via Cu(1) atom to form a 1-D zigzag chain structure. In the crystal packing structure of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each 1-D zigzag chain structures are extended along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis. cln_elements.clean_text:
The average Cu(1)-N distance of 2.062(3) Å in the chelate site is similar to that (2.006(3) Å) in the terminal site and that (1.979(4) Å) in MeCN. The N-Cu(1)-N angle is also in the ranges of 107.5(1) - 126.6(1) °. Although the dihedral angle of 15.40° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (A) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (C) is slightly larger than that (9.81°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (A), it can be regarded that the 2,2':5',4"-terpy ligand is nearly planar. On the other hand, the dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(1), N(1), C(1) and C(5)} and {Cu(1), N(2') and N(3')} atoms is 67.98° around the Cu(1) atom. For this reason, two neighboring 2,2':5',4"-terpy are largely bent each other via Cu(1) atom to form a 1-D zigzag chain structure. In the crystal packing structure of complex 1, each 1-D zigzag chain structures are extended along the b-axis. The infinite 1-D zigzag-chains are apparently stacking parallel to each other against the bc plane, along with the centroid⋯centroid distance of 3.754Å and the inter-planar angle of 15.04° between the opposite central 2-pyridyl ring and terminal 4-pyridyl ring. However, the Cu(I)⋯Cu(I) distance of 6.364Å is located far away. Therefore, it is considered that there is no specific intermolecular interaction such as π⋯π stacking, CH⋯π and Cu(I)⋯Cu(I) interactions judging from the distances and the angles. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in  (a).

{{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2)

To investigate the role of an anion in the formation process relative to complex 1, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 (in place of a BF4 - anion) with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in MeOH/MeCN under Ar/C2H4 afforded brick reddish brown crystals of {{[Cu(2,2':5',4"-terpy)(MeCN)]PF6}2⋅H2O}n (2). Unlike complex 1, there are two independent infinite 1-D zigzag chain structures containing Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms in the unit cell ( ). Both Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms are coordinated by one N atom in the terminal site of 2,2':5',4"-terpy, one N atom of MeCN and two N atoms in the chelate site of another 2,2':5',4"-terpy in the tetrahedral geometry. Although two independent 1-D zigzag chain structures apparently have a similar structure, it should be noted that one infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure (chains (a): blue) containing the Cu(1) atom are extended along the c-axis and the other infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure (chains (b): green) containing the Cu(2) atom are extended along the b-axis. The crossed zigzag chains are stacking parallel to each other against the ac plane ( ). In both of the chains (a) and (b), the weak intermolecular π⋯π stacking interactions meaningfully exist between opposite 2,2':5',4"-terpy ligands in the adjacent zigzag chains [the chain (a): centroid⋯centroid distance between central pyridyl rings=3.623Å, internal angle between central pyridyl rings=0°, centroid⋯centroid distance between terminal 2-pyridyl ring and terminal 4-pyridyl ring=3.653Å, internal angle between terminal 2-pyridyl ring and terminal 4-pyridyl ring=5.58°; the chain (b): centroid⋯centroid distance between central pyridyl ring and terminal 2-pyridyl ring=3.567Å, internal angle between central pyridyl ring and terminal 2-pyridyl ring=4.34°]. Another remarkably structural feature is that the PF6 - anions are surrounded by four opposite MeCN molecules in two crossed zigzag chains (a) and (b). In our previous works, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 with pprd under C2H4 afforded polymeric Cu(I)-pprd complex {[Cu(pprd)(C2H4)]PF6}n and tetranuclear Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu4(pprd)4(C2H4)4](PF6)4 . Therefore, the infinite 1-D zigzag chain structure is different from structures of complex 1 and the previous Cu(I)-pprd-C2H4 complexes . This result indicates that the PF6 - anions can play here a significant role as an anion template to form the crossed zigzag chain structure.

[Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3)

To investigate the role of a solvent in the formation process relative to complex 2, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]PF6 with 2,2':5',4"-terpy in Me2CO/MeCN (in place of MeOH/MeCN) under Ar/C2H4 afforded plate orange crystals of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4](PF6)4⋅5Me2CO (3). Unlike complexes 1 and 2, the X-ray crystal analysis showed that there are one [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ cation moiety, four PF6 - anions and five solvated Me2CO molecules in a unit cell. Four Cu(I) atoms are bridged by the four 2,2':5',4"-terpy in a head-to-tail fashion to afford a rhombic Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy metallomacrocycle ( (a)). The Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) and Cu(1)⋯Cu(2') distances are 9.742 and 10.077Å, and the internal Cu(1)⋯Cu(2)⋯Cu(1') and Cu(2)⋯Cu(1)⋯Cu(2') angles are 103.80 and 76.20°. It should be noted that these rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ cores are stacking parallel to each other against the bc plane (along the a-axis). The one side of four sides in the rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core is alternately overlapping at intervals of the Cu(I)⋯Cu(I) contact of 3.402Å. Furthermore, one distorted Me2CO molecule is encapsulated in the central vacant space of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core and two PF6 - anions are sandwiched between the rhombic Cu(I) metallomacrocyclic layers ((b)). Therefore, this result shows that the PF6 - anions and the Me2CO molecules can serve here as a template to form a rhombic tetranuclear Cu(I) metallomacrocycle. The planar structure of [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core is different from the matallocalix[4]-shaped structure of Cu(I)-pprd complex [Cu4(pprd)4(C2H4)4](PF6)4 encapsulating PF6 - anion in our previous works .

cln_elements.content: <ce:para id="p0095" view="all">In the rhombic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> core, the Cu(1)-N(5′) distance of 2.142 Å is slightly longer than two other Cu(1)-N distances (Cu(1)-N(1) = 1.911 Å, Cu(1)-N(6′) = 1.961 Å) around the Cu(1) atom. The N(6′)-Cu(1)-N(5′) angle of 80.76° is larger than two other <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-Cu(1)-N angles (N(6′)-Cu(1)-N(1) = 151.38, N(5′)-Cu(1)-N(1) = 127.84°). In similarly, the Cu(2)-N(3) distance of 2.092 Å is slightly longer than two other Cu(2)-N distances (Cu(2)-N(2) = 1.960 Å, Cu(2)-N(4) = 1.905 Å) around the Cu(2) atom. The N(2)-Cu(2)-N(3) angle of 81.62° is larger than two other <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-Cu(2)-N angles (N(2)-Cu(2)-N(4) = 157.31°, N(3)-Cu(2)-N(4) = 121.07°). In addition, the sum of the three internal angles around the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atom are 359.98° and 360.00°, respectively. Therefore, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms have a unique Y-shape triangular planar structure . Unlike complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, MeCN is not coordinate to the Cu(I) atom as an ancillary ligand. In the short side of rhombic [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> core, the dihedral angle of 25.95° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (C) is larger than that (6.32°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (A). Similarly, in the long side, the dihedral angle of 19.97° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (E) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (F) is larger than that (4.83°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (E) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (D). The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(1), N(1), C(1) and C(5)} and {Cu(1), N(5′) and N(6′)} atoms is 21.24° around the Cu(1) atom. The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(2), N(4), C(16) and C(20)} and {Cu(2), N(2) and N(3)} atoms is 26.01° around the Cu(2) atom. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in (c).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st105">Spectroscopic characterizations of Cu(I)-2,2′:5′,4″-terpy complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are insoluble in normal organic solvents. We are currently unable to obtain appropriate UV–VIS and <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra in solution. Alternatively, we have characterized spectroscopically complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> by IR and UV–VIS measurements in the solid state. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> showed the IR absorption bands for ν<ce:inf loc="post">C=C,</ce:inf> ν<ce:inf loc="post">C=N,</ce:inf> ν<ce:inf loc="post">C-C,</ce:inf> ν<ce:inf loc="post">C-N</ce:inf> stretching vibrations in the ranges of <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 1600–1300 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in  and . These IR absorption patterns were changed relative to those of metal-free 2,2′:5′,4″-terpy in  and , along with the strong absorption bands of 1060 (BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>), 840 (PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>), 844 (PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>) and 1363 (NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The UV−VIS spectra of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in the solid state are shown in . Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> gave the relatively distinct absorption at λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> = 400, 400 and 425 nm, respectively, whereas complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibited the gentle absorption at λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> = 410 nm as a shoulder. These absorptions were assigned as the charge-transfer transition (MLCT) band from the dπ(Cu) orbital to the π*(2,2′:5′,4″-terpy) orbital.</ce:para>

In the rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core, the Cu(1)-N(5') distance of 2.142Å is slightly longer than two other Cu(1)-N distances (Cu(1)-N(1)=1.911Å, Cu(1)-N(6')=1.961Å) around the Cu(1) atom. The N(6')-Cu(1)-N(5') angle of 80.76° is larger than two other N-Cu(1)-N angles (N(6')-Cu(1)-N(1)=151.38, N(5')-Cu(1)-N(1)=127.84°). In similarly, the Cu(2)-N(3) distance of 2.092Å is slightly longer than two other Cu(2)-N distances (Cu(2)-N(2)=1.960Å, Cu(2)-N(4)=1.905Å) around the Cu(2) atom. The N(2)-Cu(2)-N(3) angle of 81.62° is larger than two other N-Cu(2)-N angles (N(2)-Cu(2)-N(4)=157.31°, N(3)-Cu(2)-N(4)=121.07°). In addition, the sum of the three internal angles around the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atom are 359.98° and 360.00°, respectively. Therefore, the Cu(1) and Cu(2) atoms have a unique Y-shape triangular planar structure . Unlike complexes 1 and 2, MeCN is not coordinate to the Cu(I) atom as an ancillary ligand. In the short side of rhombic [Cu4(2,2':5',4"-terpy)4]4+ core, the dihedral angle of 25.95° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (C) is larger than that (6.32°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (B) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (A). Similarly, in the long side, the dihedral angle of 19.97° between the central 2-pyridyl ring (E) and the terminal 4-pyridyl ring (F) is larger than that (4.83°) between the central 2-pyridyl ring (E) and the terminal 2-pyridyl ring (D). The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(1), N(1), C(1) and C(5)} and {Cu(1), N(5') and N(6')} atoms is 21.24° around the Cu(1) atom. The dihedral angle between two planes defined by {Cu(2), N(4), C(16) and C(20)} and {Cu(2), N(2) and N(3)} atoms is 26.01° around the Cu(2) atom. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in (c).

Spectroscopic characterizations of Cu(I)-2,2':5',4"-terpy complexes

Complexes 1-4 are insoluble in normal organic solvents. We are currently unable to obtain appropriate UV-VIS and 1H NMR spectra in solution. Alternatively, we have characterized spectroscopically complexes 1-4 by IR and UV-VIS measurements in the solid state. Complexes 1-4 showed the IR absorption bands for νC=C, νC=N, νC-C, νC-N stretching vibrations in the ranges of ca. 1600-1300cm-1 in  and . These IR absorption patterns were changed relative to those of metal-free 2,2':5',4"-terpy in  and , along with the strong absorption bands of 1060 (BF4), 840 (PF6), 844 (PF6) and 1363 (NO3) cm-1 for complexes 1-4, respectively.

The UV-VIS spectra of complexes 1-4 in the solid state are shown in . Complex 1, 2 and 4 gave the relatively distinct absorption at λmax=400, 400 and 425nm, respectively, whereas complex 3 exhibited the gentle absorption at λmax=410nm as a shoulder. These absorptions were assigned as the charge-transfer transition (MLCT) band from the dπ(Cu) orbital to the π*(2,2':5',4"-terpy) orbital.
